instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3747: What is 820-3747? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKLT_PWM: What is BKLT_PWM? BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKLT_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3747</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> Low.
threads.message:
Macbook air no backlight with no real history. Board has been cleaned with liquid indicators tripped. 

There is an image on screen, just no backlight

<SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> (With Screen) - 1.47V

<SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> (Without Screen)-  2.6V (without screen)

<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> - 2.7V

Changed driver with no change. Also replaced <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR> with no change.

Diode mode on <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> - .526

Should I assume bad CPU/PCH on this...?

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3747</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> Low.
threads.message: Nah I don't think so. What voltage are you getting on backlight currently? Also diode mode on backlight output?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3747</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> Low.
threads.message:
Check continuity between <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> and A5 ball of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>.
Pay atention to XW7720 bridge.
Search the forum for that and you will find some recent threads with detailed explanations...
Post voltages for <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3747</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> Low.
threads.message: Will get back with that info. Thanks guys!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3747</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> Low.
threads.message:
This is all set. Thanks guys!!

Have a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3747</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> Low.
threads.message:
Please leave a feedback about your solution.
This can help someone else in the future...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3747</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> Low.
threads.message:
There happened to be a slight crack on pin 1 side of L7701. No sure how that would cause <SIGNAL>BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> to be low, but it works.

Thanks, have a good one.
